news_header: A study finds that children who experienced sugar rationing during WWII are less likely to develop chronic illnesses later in life.
news_text: Research indicates that limiting added sugars during the first 1,000 days of life can reduce the risk of chronic health issues such as diabetes and hypertension in adulthood. A study leveraging data from the UK Biobank found that individuals who experienced sugar rationing during WWII had significantly lower risks of developing these conditions compared to those who did not. The findings highlight the importance of early nutrition and suggest that reducing added sugar intake is crucial for long-term health.
